abstracts.cdata!:
The Electricity Privatization Adjustment
            Loan (EPAL) Project's outcome is satisfactory, with
            sustainability likely. Bank performance was highly
            satisfactory in identification and preparation, and
            satisfactory for appraisal and supervision. While the
            Borrowers performance was satisfactory for preparation and
            implementation, it was unsatisfactory in the area of
            covenant compliance. Key lessons learned follow. A complete
            reform of the electricity sector is a long-term proposition
            requiring a firm focus on fundamental requirements with a
            flexible legal framework. Governments need to retain high
            quality staff familiar with the private sector. Maintaining
            the autonomy of regulatory agencies is a constant struggle.
            It is important to move quickly when privatizing, and close
            coordination between key agencies is required. Tariff
            increases should be made well before privatization
            commences. The government needs to carry out studies of the
            effects of privatization and adequately communicate the
            results. The Bank, when making sectoral reform loans, should
            include all major components of the sector, give supervision
            appropriate priority, and attempt to understanding the
            source of major obstacles rather than focusing on the legal
            and administrative aspects of project implementation.
            Combining adjustment lending with technical assistance
            provides an effective was of ensuring that the Government
            has the funds to carry out the necessary preparations for reforms.
